Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant met the residency requirements under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Chin Wu was absent for 739 days and present for 721 days over the four-year period; absences were for family and personal reasons, not temporary employment or study abroad
Court_Ruling: The appeal is dismissed as the applicant did not meet the residency requirement
Defendant_Behavior: Extended absence from Canada totaling 739 days over four years
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to accumulate at least 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada
Legal_Standard: Minimum 1,095 days of residence in Canada within a four-year period
Assessment_Factor: Duration and nature of absences from Canada
Applicable_Legislation: Citizenship Act, paragraph 5(1)(c); Federal Courts Act, section 21
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to Federal Court under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Review_Standard: Statutory interpretation and factual assessment of residency
Evidence_Used: Record of entry and exit dates, applicant’s explanation for absences
Legal_Provision_Cited: Citizenship Act, paragraph 5(1)(c); Federal Courts Act, section 21
Application_Basis: Physical presence calculation based on immigration records
Evidence_Assessed: Days of presence and absence documented in official records
Relief_Sought: Judicial review and approval of citizenship application
Governing_Rule: Applicants must be physically present in Canada for at least 1,095 days within four years prior to application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient days of physical presence (721 days instead of required 1,095)
Cause_Description: Chin Wu's application for citizenship was denied due to insufficient residency days
Evidence_Handling: Official immigration records used to calculate presence and absence
Evidence_Assessment: Absences not eligible for exemption under temporary employment or study provisions
Decision_Rationale: The applicant failed to meet the statutory physical presence requirement of 1,095 days
Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective calculation of physical presence under the Citizenship Act
